awd_titl_txt: Extending the Reach of Mathematics Teacher Leaders
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the development of mathematics teacher leaders' capacity to engage in systemic leadership activities. The model for developing this capacity will be based on the concept that teacher leadership work can be conceived of as having levels, similar to the idea of management levels. In this model, Tier I teacher leadership activities are those that leverage teachers' knowledge, experience, and motivation to support effective instruction in classrooms outside their own. Tier I teacher leadership activities have a close proximity to and thus directly influence teachers' instruction. Tier II teacher leadership activities are those that leverage teacher leaders' knowledge, experience, and motivation to improve systems that support effective instruction. This model is predicated on two positions:  (1) Tier II leadership activities necessitate the employment of knowledge and skills different from those required for Tier I leadership activities; and (2) Productive systemic change can occur by supporting teacher leaders to expand their work into Tier II leadership activities. This project will develop teacher leaders' knowledge and skills to engage in Tier II activities and to further theorize and evaluate the conceptualization and operationalization of Tier I and Tier II leadership activities in teacher leadership development. 

This project will implement and evaluate a teacher leader development model that will build the capacity of Tier I and Tier II teacher leaders in their respective leadership capacity. In the teacher leader development model, Tier II teacher leaders will receive training and mentoring to 1) train Tier I teacher leaders to implement the professional development with classroom teachers and 2) oversee broader implementation issues, such as developing district support for the professional development and supporting the creation and implementation of an evaluation plan for the professional development. The professional development will consist of a sequence of nine, 90-minute sessions that will support elementary teachers in developing a rich conceptualization of multiplication of whole numbers. Through this vehicle of implementing a mathematics professional development program, both sets of teacher leaders will receive training and mentoring to develop their knowledge, skills, and dispositions to engage in their tier of teacher leadership activities. Teachers will then be positioned to leverage their increased leadership capacity to engage in other Tier I and II teacher leadership activities that support the improvement of STEM education. The evaluation of the implementation of the leadership development model will help the field understand the key characteristics that support the effectiveness of the training. Additionally, in their roles as ambassadors for K-12 mathematics education, Tier II teacher leaders will work at the nexus of policy, practice, and STEM education research through Tier II policy activities. Teachers will then be positioned to leverage their increased leadership capacity to engage in other Tier I and II teacher leadership activities that support the improvement of STEM education. The design of the teacher leader development model can be scaled through any STEM professional development, when it is paired with the teacher leader training of Tier I teacher leaders. Although the project involves mathematics teachers and teacher leaders, it has the potential to inform teacher leadership development and effectiveness across the STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
The Extending the Reach of Mathematics Teacher Leaders project was based on the concept that teacher leadership work can be conceived of as Tier I and Tier II teacher leadership activities, a concept which has not been formalized within teacher leadership scholarship. Tier 1 activities leverage teachers? knowledge, experience, and motivation to support effective instruction in classrooms outside their own. Tier II teacher leadership activities leverage teacher leaders? knowledge, experience, and motivation to improve systems that support effective instruction. We call teacher leaders engaged in primarily Tier 2 activities T2s and in primarily Tier 1 activities T1s. We engaged 12 math teacher leaders (T2s) from Colorado and New Mexico in Tier II activities organized around the implementation of a cascade (train-the-trainer) model for professional development for elementary school teachers on the topic of multi-digit multiplication (MMPD). These Tier II activities included:

  • working with district decision makers to understand and negotiate the implementation of the cascade model
  • recruit and train teachers (T1 math leaders) to implement the MMPD
  • recruit elementary teachers to participate in the MMPD
  • design an evaluation plan to evaluate the implementation with the T1s and the teachers

As the T2s engaged in these activities, they built the knowledge, skills and dispositions required to take on systemic change to support effective instruction in K12 mathematics.

Intellectual Merit

Our project evaluation of the conceptualization and operationalization of Tier I and Tier II leadership activities in teacher leadership development suggests that both T1s and T2s developed knowledge, skills and dispositions appropriate for the activities they engaged in and were effective in their respective activities. Prior engagement in T1 activities in a variety of districts and through a variety of programs seems to have prepared our T2 participants to engage effectively, by a variety of measures, in T2 activities with the support and training offered them in this project. For many T1s, their involvement in this project was their first foray into math teacher leadership. On average, the T1s were not experienced PD facilitators and had some weaknesses in their content knowledge. Throughout T1s involvement, evaluation suggests they deepened their content knowledge of mathematics at the elementary level and developed facilitation skills to deliver the PD. These claims are supported by the high degree of satisfaction the T2s, T1s and teachers who received the PD expressed about their professional learning opportunities.

We established math task design criteria for the cascade model to address criticisms associated with fidelity of implementation and effectiveness which suffer with each layer of trainers.  Here are the criteria.

  • Tasks are designed so math ideas and connections are explicitly embedded in a task so teachers interact with them by doing the task.
  • The mathematical ideas a task is developing are explicitly articulated so that the purpose of the task is clear to the facilitator and the learners
  • Tasks support teachers to develop meanings for mathematical objects and ideas.
  • Tasks supports teacher to construct connections within and across tasks and to see mathematics as a coherent whole, not a collection of independent skills and procedures.
  • Tasks ask teachers to articulate why and how mathematical ideas are connected in order to support and to see mathematics as comprehensible, not a collection of tricks to be memorized.
  • Tasks are sequenced to revisit, extend and connect meanings in previous tasks and to practice the reasoning about how and why mathematical ideas/meanings are connected.

Tasks meet teachers where they are mathematically and build on their knowledge and experience teaching mathematics to children.

These criteria can be used by others in the development of math professional development and can likely be adapted for use in science professional development with the cascade model.

Broader Impacts

This project built and implemented a model for developing Tier II mathematics leadership capacity to influence systemic improvements in mathematics education. This work resulted in 4 trained T3s, 12 T2s, 55 T1s and professional development delivered to about 250 elementary teachers. T3s are T2s who learned how to develop professional development for the cascade model. The cascade model?s power is that the T2s can train more T1s to deliver the MMPD and the T1s can offer the MMPD to more elementary teachers. As a result, we have permanently increased the capacity of these professionals to offer high quality mathematics PD and increased the leadership capacity of the districts in which these teachers work.  A key component in developing T2 and T1 math leaders was the elementary mathematics professional development materials the project developed and refined. Those materials are now available at mathplaydream.com at no charge. These materials, developed for the cascade model, focus on three topics: multiplying multi-digit whole numbers, what is a fraction, and engaging with addition and subtraction of whole numbers through a lens of place value.  This collection represents about 29 hours of professional development.
